I wrote a short story over the summer while attending the Writer's Retreat at the Hemmingway-Pfieffer Educational Center.  There is one main character, an older lady like myself who is now retired with too much time on her hands.  I decided to have her try and become a “bag lady”, joining the homeless who live under a bridge in north Jonesboro.  It was my first experience using dialogue to give the reader insight into this character and the group of people she meets and tries to befriend.  It was especially important to show the way the words of each individual were spoken because of the difference in their social and economic worlds.  I titled my story “Jane, The Baglady.”  To give the reader some background into Jane before she had an dialogue I explained that she taught school for many years and had tried to land a couple of jobs, but was unsuccessful mostly due to her age and lack of experience in the fields she sought employment.  Having made a decision to become a bag lady, goes to this bridge, leaves her car, and has her first encounter with a homeless person.  In Jane's mind, she needs a grocery cart, so begins the conversation (dialogue) between the two:  Seeking the most likely person to engage in conversation with, she approaches a man squatting in front of a makeshift hut.  

 

“Hello, I’m Jane.  Nice to meet you.  I’m going to be your neighbor. Is the space beside you taken?”

 

He looks up at her as though she was from Mars.  

 

“I’m not the mayor of this place” he says, waving his hand in a large arc for effect.  “You can settle in anywhere you see a space.  Did you walk over from town?  I’ve never seen you on the strip.  What is your name?”

 

“I told you it is Jane and I need a grocery cart too” Jane replies beginning to get exasperated . “Where might I procure such cart?”

 

“Huh”, he shrugs, “I don’t know you.  We ain’t a, you know, community.  It is every man for himself.”

I wrote a short story over the summer while attending the Writer's Retreat at the Hemmingway-Pfieffer Educational Center.  There is one main character, an older lady like myself who is now retired with too much time on her hands.  I decided to have her try and become a “bag lady”, joining the homeless who live under a bridge in north Jonesboro.  It was my first experience using dialogue to give the reader insight into this character and the group of people she meets and tries to befriend.  It was especially important to show the way the words of each individual were spoken because of the difference in their social and economic worlds.  I titled my story “Jane, The Baglady.”  To give the reader some background into Jane before she had an dialogue I explained that she taught school for many years and had tried to land a couple of jobs, but was unsuccessful mostly due to her age and lack of experience in the fields she sought employment.  Having made a decision to become a bag lady, goes to this bridge, leaves her car, and has her first encounter with a homeless person.  In Jane's mind, she needs a grocery cart, so begins the conversation (dialogue) between the two:  Seeking the most likely person to engage in conversation with, she approaches a man squatting in front of a makeshift hut.  

 

                            “Hello, I’m Jane.  Nice to meet you.  I’m going to be your neighbor. Is the space beside you taken?”

 

                              He looks up at her as though she was from Mars.  

 

                             “I’m not the mayor of this place” he says, waving his hand in a large arc for effect. 

 

                             “You can settle in anywhere you see a space.  Did you walk over from town?  I never seen you on the strip. 

 

                             What's your name?”

“I told you it is Jane and I need a grocery cart too” Jane replies beginning to get exasperated . “Where might I procure such cart?”

 

“Huh”, he shrugs, “I don’t know you.  We ain’t a, you know, community.  It is every man for himself.”

I wrote a short story over the summer while attending the Writer's Retreat at the Hemmingway-Pfieffer Educational Center.  There is one main character, an older lady like myself who is now retired with too much time on her hands.  I decided to have her try and become a “bag lady”, joining the homeless who live under a bridge in north Jonesboro.  It was my first experience using dialogue to give the reader insight into this character and the group of people she meets and tries to befriend.  It was especially important to show the way the words of each individual were spoken because of the difference in their social and economic worlds.  I titled my story “Jane, The Baglady.”  To give the reader some background into Jane before she had an dialogue I explained that she taught school for many years and had tried to land a couple of jobs, but was unsuccessful mostly due to her age and lack of experience in the fields she sought employment.  Having made a decision to become a bag lady, goes to this bridge, leaves her car, and has her first encounter with a homeless person.  In Jane's mind, she needs a grocery cart, so begins the conversation (dialogue) between the two:  Seeking the most likely person to engage in conversation with, she approaches a man squatting in front of a makeshift hut.  

 

                            “Hello, I’m Jane.  Nice to meet you.  I’m going to be your neighbor. Is the space beside you taken?”

 

                              He looks up at her as though she was from Mars.  

 

                             “I’m not the mayor of this place” he says, waving his hand in a large arc for effect. 

 

                             “You can settle in anywhere you see a space.  Did you walk over from town?  I never seen you on the strip. 

 

                             What's your name?”

 

                            “I told you it is Jane and I need a grocery cart too” Jane replies beginning to get exasperated . 

 

                            “Where might I procure such cart?”

 

                            “Huh”, he shrugs, “I don’t know you.  We ain’t a, you know, community.  It's every man for himself.”

I wrote a short story over the summer while attending the Writer's Retreat at the Hemmingway-Pfieffer Educational Center.  There is one main character, an older lady like myself who is now retired with too much time on her hands.  I decided to have her try and become a “bag lady”, joining the homeless who live under a bridge in north Jonesboro.  It was my first experience using dialogue to give the reader insight into this character and the group of people she meets and tries to befriend.  It was especially important to show the way the words of each individual were spoken because of the difference in their social and economic worlds.  I titled my story “Jane, The Baglady.”  To give the reader some background into Jane before she had an dialogue I explained that she taught school for many years and had tried to land a couple of jobs, but was unsuccessful mostly due to her age and lack of experience in the fields she sought employment.  Having made a decision to become a bag lady, goes to this bridge, leaves her car, and has her first encounter with a homeless person.  In Jane's mind, she needs a grocery cart, so begins the conversation (dialogue) between the two:  Seeking the most likely person to engage in conversation with, she approaches a man squatting in front of a makeshift hut.  

 

                            “Hello, I’m Jane.  Nice to meet you.  I’m going to be your neighbor. Is the space beside you taken?”

 

                              He looks up at her as though she was from Mars.  

 

                             “I’m not the mayor of this place” he says, waving his hand in a large arc for effect. 

 

                             “You can settle in anywhere you see a space.  Did you walk over from town?  I never seen you on the strip. 

 

                             What's your name?”

 

                            “I told you it is Jane and I need a grocery cart too” Jane replies beginning to get exasperated . 

 

                            “Where might I procure such cart?”

 

                            “Huh”, he shrugs, “I don’t know you.  We ain’t a, you know, community.  Is every man for himself.”

 

    This short dialogue between Jane and the homeless man let the reader know Jane is not afraid to go where she has never been before and his reply reveals he isn't going to help her.

answerVersions.2023-09-10T21:23:08.309Z:
I wrote a short story over the summer while attending the Writer's Retreat at the Hemmingway-Pfieffer Educational Center.  There is one main character, an older lady like myself who is now retired with too much time on her hands.  I decided to have her try and become a “bag lady”, joining the homeless who live under a bridge in north Jonesboro.  It was my first experience using dialogue to give the reader insight into this character and the group of people she meets and tries to befriend.  It was especially important to show the way the words of each individual were spoken because of the difference in their social and economic worlds.  I titled my story “Jane, The Baglady.”  To give the reader some background into Jane before she had an dialogue I explained that she taught school for many years and had tried to land a couple of jobs, but was unsuccessful mostly due to her age and lack of experience in the fields she sought employment.  Having made a decision to become a bag lady, goes to this bridge, leaves her car, and has her first encounter with a homeless person.  In Jane's mind, she needs a grocery cart, so begins the conversation (dialogue) between the two:  Seeking the most likely person to engage in conversation with, she approaches a man squatting in front of a makeshift hut.  

 

                            “Hello, I’m Jane.  Nice to meet you.  I’m going to be your neighbor. Is the space beside you taken?”

 

                              He looks up at her as though she was from Mars.  

 

                             “I’m not the mayor of this place” he says, waving his hand in a large arc for effect. 

 

                             “You can settle in anywhere you see a space.  Did you walk over from town?  I never seen you on the strip. 

 

                             What's your name?”

 

                            “I told you it is Jane and I need a grocery cart too” Jane replies beginning to get exasperated . 

 

                            “Where might I procure such cart?”

 

                            “Huh”, he shrugs, “I don’t know you.  We ain’t a, you know, community.  Is every man for himself.”

 

            This short dialogue between Jane and the homeless man let the reader know Jane is not afraid to go where she has never been                                   before and his reply reveals he isn't going to help her.  Her vocabulary is richer and proper.  His indicates to the reader that he probably hasn't had a lot of education.  After all he is homeless.  Was I successful in giving the reader an image of each character?

                              He looks up at her as though she was from Mars.  

 

                             “I’m not the mayor of this place” he says, waving his hand in a large arc for effect. 

 

                             “You can settle in anywhere you see a space.  Did you walk over from town?  I never seen you on the strip. 

 

                             What's your name?”

 

                            “I told you it is Jane and I need a grocery cart too” Jane replies beginning to get exasperated . 

 

                            “Where might I procure such cart?”

 

                            “Huh”, he shrugs, “I don’t know you.  We ain’t a, you know, community.  Is every man for himself.”

 

            This short dialogue between Jane and the homeless man let the reader know Jane is not afraid to go where she has never been                                   before and his reply reveals he isn't going to help her.  Her vocabulary is richer and proper.  His indicates to the reader that he probably hasn't had a lot of education.  After all he is homeless.  Was I successful in giving the reader an image of each character?  If the reader has any prior knowledge of a homeless person, male or female walking down a city street pushing a grocery cart, and living in a box, the

I wrote a short story over the summer while attending the Writer's Retreat at the Hemmingway-Pfieffer Educational Center.  There is one main character, an older lady like myself who is now retired with too much time on her hands.  I decided to have her try and become a “bag lady”, joining the homeless who live under a bridge in north Jonesboro.  It was my first experience using dialogue to give the reader insight into this character and the group of people she meets and tries to befriend.  It was especially important to show the way the words of each individual were spoken because of the difference in their social and economic worlds.  I titled my story “Jane, The Baglady.”  To give the reader some background into Jane before she had an dialogue I explained that she taught school for many years and had tried to land a couple of jobs, but was unsuccessful mostly due to her age and lack of experience in the fields she sought employment.  Having made a decision to become a bag lady, goes to this bridge, leaves her car, and has her first encounter with a homeless person.  In Jane's mind, she needs a grocery cart, so begins the conversation (dialogue) between the two:  Seeking the most likely person to engage in conversation with, she approaches a man squatting in front of a makeshift hut.  

 

                            “Hello, I’m Jane.  Nice to meet you.  I’m going to be your neighbor. Is the space beside you taken?”

 

                              He looks up at her as though she was from Mars.  

 

                             “I’m not the mayor of this place” he says, waving his hand in a large arc for effect. 

 

                             “You can settle in anywhere you see a space.  Did you walk over from town?  I never seen you on the strip. 

 

                             What's your name?”

 

                            “I told you it is Jane and I need a grocery cart too” Jane replies beginning to get exasperated . 

 

                            “Where might I procure such cart?”

 

                            “Huh”, he shrugs, “I don’t know you.  We ain’t a, you know, community.  Is every man for himself.”

I wrote a short story over the summer while attending the Writer's Retreat at the Hemmingway-Pfieffer Educational Center.  There is one main character, an older lady like myself who is now retired with too much time on her hands.  I decided to have her try and become a “bag lady”, joining the homeless who live under a bridge in north Jonesboro.  It was my first experience using dialogue to give the reader insight into this character and the group of people she meets and tries to befriend.  It was especially important to show the way the words of each individual were spoken because of the difference in their social and economic worlds.  I titled my story “Jane, The Baglady.”  To give the reader some background into Jane before she had an dialogue I explained that she taught school for many years and had tried to land a couple of jobs, but was unsuccessful mostly due to her age and lack of experience in the fields she sought employment.  Having made a decision to become a bag lady, goes to this bridge, leaves her car, and has her first encounter with a homeless person.  In Jane's mind, she needs a grocery cart, so begins the conversation (dialogue) between the two:  Seeking the most likely person to engage in conversation with, she approaches a man squatting in front of a makeshift hut.  

 

                            “Hello, I’m Jane.  Nice to meet you.  I’m going to be your neighbor. Is the space beside you taken?”

                             “I’m not the mayor of this place” he says, waving his hand in a large arc for effect. 

 

                             “You can settle in anywhere you see a space.  Did you walk over from town?  I never seen you on the strip. 

 

                             What's your name?”

                            “Hello, I’m Jane.  Nice to meet you.  I’m going to be your neighbor. Is the space beside you taken?”

 

                              He looks up at her as though she was from Mars.  

 

                             “I’m not the mayor of this place” he says, waving his hand in a large arc for effect. 

 

                             “You can settle in anywhere you see a space.  Did you walk over from town?  I never seen you on the strip. 

 

                             What's your name?”

 

                            “I told you it is Jane and I need a grocery cart too” Jane replies beginning to get exasperated . 

 

                            “Where might I procure such cart?”

 

                            “Huh”, he shrugs, “I don’t know you.  We ain’t a, you know, community.  Is every man for himself.”

 

            This short dialogue between Jane and the homeless man let the reader know Jane is not afraid to go where she has never been                                   before and his reply reveals he isn't going to help her.  Her vocabulary is richer and proper.  His indicates to the reader that he probably hasn't had a lot of education.  After all he is homeless.  Was I successful in giving the reader an image of each character?  If the reader has any prior knowledge of a homeless person, male or female walking down a city street pushing a grocery cart, and living in a box, then yes this dialogue has succeeded in giving the reader a more complete picture of the characters.  My character Jane has one more encounter with a group of women before she gives up and leaves the shanty surroundings:

                            

                            “Excuse me, can any of you give me some information about residing here and acquiring a grocery cart?” 

 

                            “We ain’t got no grocery carts.    Might can hang around the parking lot at the Price Chopper see if you can grab one left 

 

                            outside after they closes.  Round 10:00  tonight.”

 

                            “Oh, I didn’t know they are that hard to get.  Can’t I buy one?” Jane inquires.  

 

                            “Buy one? Lady you be lucky to find one with four wheels and one them handles to push it.  

 

                             We never had no high society beggar woman here before. You need to move on.”

I wrote a short story over the summer while attending the Writer's Retreat at the Hemmingway-Pfieffer Educational Center.  There is one main character, an older lady like myself who is now retired with too much time on her hands.  I decided to have her try and become a “bag lady”, joining the homeless who live under a bridge in north Jonesboro.  It was my first experience using dialogue to give the reader insight into this character and the group of people she meets and tries to befriend.  It was especially important to show the way the words of each individual were spoken because of the difference in their social and economic worlds.  I titled my story “Jane, The Baglady.”  To give the reader some background into Jane before she had an dialogue I explained that she taught school for many years and had tried to land a couple of jobs, but was unsuccessful mostly due to her age and lack of experience in the fields she sought employment.  Having made a decision to become a bag lady, goes to this bridge, leaves her car, and has her first encounter with a homeless person.  In Jane's mind, she needs a grocery cart, so begins the conversation (dialogue) between the two:  Seeking the most likely person to engage in conversation with, she approaches a man squatting in front of a makeshift hut.  

 

                            “Hello, I’m Jane.  Nice to meet you.  I’m going to be your neighbor. Is the space beside you taken?”

 

                              He looks up at her as though she was from Mars.  

 

                             “I’m not the mayor of this place” he says, waving his hand in a large arc for effect. 

 

                             “You can settle in anywhere you see a space.  Did you walk over from town?  I never seen you on the strip. 

 

                             What's your name?”

 

                            “I told you it is Jane and I need a grocery cart too” Jane replies beginning to get exasperated . 

 

                            “Where might I procure such cart?”

 

                            “Huh”, he shrugs, “I don’t know you.  We ain’t a, you know, community.  Is every man for himself.”

                             “I’m not the mayor of this place” he says, waving his hand in a large arc for effect.

                            “Hello, I’m Jane.  Nice to meet you.  I’m going to be your neighbor. Is the space beside you taken?”

 

                              He looks up at her as though she was from Mars.  

 

                             “I’m not the mayor of this place” he says, waving his hand in a large arc for effect. 

 

                             “You can settle in anywhere you see a space.  Did you walk over from town?  I never seen you on the strip. 

 

                             What's your name?”

 

                            “I told you it is Jane and I need a grocery cart too” Jane replies beginning to get exasperated . 

 

                            “Where might I procure such cart?”

 

                            “Huh”, he shrugs, “I don’t know you.  We ain’t a, you know, community.  Is every man for himself.”

 

            This short dialogue between Jane and the homeless man let the reader know Jane is not afraid to go where she has never been                                   before and his reply reveals he isn't going to help her.  Her vocabulary is richer and proper.  His indicates to the reader that he probably hasn't had a lot of education.  After all he is homeless.  Was I successful in giving the reader an image of each character?  If the reader has any prior knowledge of a homeless person, male or female walking down a city street pushing a grocery cart, and living in a box, then yes this dialogue has succeeded in giving the reader a more complete picture of the characters.  My character Jane has one more encounter with a group of women before she gives up and leaves the shanty surroundings:

                            

                            “Excuse me, can any of you give me some information about residing here and acquiring a grocery cart?” 

 

                            “We ain’t got no grocery carts.    Might can hang around the parking lot at the Price Chopper see if you can grab one left 

 

                            outside after they closes.  Round 10:00  tonight.”

 

                            “Oh, I didn’t know they are that hard to get.  Can’t I buy one?” Jane inquires.  

 

                            “Buy one? Lady you be lucky to find one with four wheels and one them handles to push it.  

 

                             We never had no high society beggar woman here before. You need to move on.”

 

Jane stays polite, on point to achieve her goal of finding a place to bed down for the night and getting that all important grocery cart, a prop she thinks is part of the whole homeless experience.  The woman she talks to suggests through dialogue that she steal one after hours at a grocery store, if she can find one that isn't missing a wheel or guiding handle.  She sizes up Jane, becomes the spokesman for the group and tells Jane not to give up trying, but to move on.

I wrote a short story over the summer while attending the Writer's Retreat at the Hemmingway-Pfieffer Educational Center.  There is one main character, an older lady like myself who is now retired with too much time on her hands.  I decided to have her try and become a “bag lady”, joining the homeless who live under a bridge in north Jonesboro.  It was my first experience using dialogue to give the reader insight into this character and the group of people she meets and tries to befriend.  It was especially important to show the way the words of each individual were spoken because of the difference in their social and economic worlds.  I titled my story “Jane, The Baglady.”  To give the reader some background into Jane before she had an dialogue I explained that she taught school for many years and had tried to land a couple of jobs, but was unsuccessful mostly due to her age and lack of experience in the fields she sought employment.  Having made a decision to become a bag lady, goes to this bridge, leaves her car, and has her first encounter with a homeless person.  In Jane's mind, she needs a grocery cart, so begins the conversation (dialogue) between the two:  Seeking the most likely person to engage in conversation with, she approaches a man squatting in front of a makeshift hut.  

 

                            “Hello, I’m Jane.  Nice to meet you.  I’m going to be your neighbor. Is the space beside you taken?”

 

                              He looks up at her as though she was from Mars.  

 

                             “I’m not the mayor of this place” he says, waving his hand in a large arc for effect. 

 

                             “You can settle in anywhere you see a space.  Did you walk over from town?  I never seen you on the strip. 

 

                             What's your name?”

 

                            “I told you it is Jane and I need a grocery cart too” Jane replies beginning to get exasperated . 

 

                            “Where might I procure such cart?”

 

                            “Huh”, he shrugs, “I don’t know you.  We ain’t a, you know, community.  Is every man for himself.”

 

            This short dialogue between Jane and the homeless man let the reader know Jane is not afraid to go where she has never been                                   before and his reply reveals he isn't going to help her.  Her vocabulary is richer and proper.  His indicates to the reader that he probably hasn't had a lot of education.  After all he is homeless.  Was I successful in giving the reader an image of each character?  If the reader has any prior knowledge of a homeless person, male or female walking down a city street pushing a grocery cart, and living in a box, then yes this dialogue has succeeded in giving the reader a more complete picture of the characters.  My character Jane has one more encounter with a group of women before she gives up and leaves the shanty surroundings:

                            

                            “Excuse me, can any of you give me some information about residing here and acquiring a grocery cart?” 

 

                            “We ain’t got no grocery carts.    Might can hang around the parking lot at the Price Chopper see if you can grab one left 

 

                            outside after they closes.  Round 10:00  tonight.”

 

                            “Oh, I didn’t know they are that hard to get.  Can’t I buy one?” Jane inquires.  

 

                            “Buy one? Lady you be lucky to find one with four wheels and one them handles to push it.  

 

                             We never had no high society beggar woman here before. You need to move on.”

 

Jane stays polite, on point to achieve her goal of finding a place to bed down for the night and getting that all important grocery cart, a prop she thinks is part of the whole homeless experience.  The woman she talks to suggests through dialogue that she steal one after hours at a grocery store, if she can find one that isn't missing a wheel or guiding handle.  She sizes up Jane, becomes the spokesman for the group and tells Jane not to give up trying, but to move on.  Direct, and to the point.  An example of the character of both women through my interpretation and unders

                             What's your name?”

 

                            “I told you it is Jane and I need a grocery cart too” Jane replies beginning to get exasperated . 

 

                            “Where might I procure such cart?”

 

                            “Huh”, he shrugs, “I don’t know you.  We ain’t a, you know, community.  Is every man for himself.”

 

            This short dialogue between Jane and the homeless man let the reader know Jane is not afraid to go where she has never been                                   before and his reply reveals he isn't going to help her.  Her vocabulary is richer and proper.  His indicates to the reader that he probably hasn't had a lot of education.  After all he is homeless.  Was I successful in giving the reader an image of each character?  If the reader has any prior knowledge of a homeless person, male or female walking down a city street pushing a grocery cart, and living in a box, then yes this dialogue has succeeded in giving the reader a more complete picture of the characters.  My character Jane has one more encounter with a group of women before she gives up and leaves the shanty surroundings:

                            

                            “Excuse me, can any of you give me some information about residing here and acquiring a grocery cart?” 

 

                            “We ain’t got no grocery carts.    Might can hang around the parking lot at the Price Chopper see if you can grab one left 

 

                            outside after they closes.  Round 10:00  tonight.”

 

                            “Oh, I didn’t know they are that hard to get.  Can’t I buy one?” Jane inquires.  

 

                            “Buy one? Lady you be lucky to find one with four wheels and one them handles to push it.  

 

                             We never had no high society beggar woman here before. You need to move on.”

 

Jane stays polite, on point to achieve her goal of finding a place to bed down for the night and getting that all important grocery cart, a prop she thinks is part of the whole homeless experience.  The woman she talks to suggests through dialogue that she steal one after hours at a grocery store, if she can find one that isn't missing a wheel or guiding handle.  She sizes up Jane, becomes the spokesman for the group and tells Jane not to give up trying, but to move on.  Direct, and to the point.  An example of the character of both women through my interpretation and understanding of these two very different individuals.

answerVersions.2023-09-10T21:41:33.557Z:
I wrote a short story over the summer while attending the Writer's Retreat at the Hemmingway-Pfieffer Educational Center.  There is one main character, an older lady like myself who is now retired with too much time on her hands.  I decided to have her try and become a “bag lady”, joining the homeless who live under a bridge in north Jonesboro.  It was my first experience using dialogue to give the reader insight into this character and the group of people she meets and tries to befriend.  It was especially important to show the way the words of each individual were spoken because of the difference in their social and economic worlds.  I titled my story “Jane, The Baglady.”  To give the reader some background into Jane before she had an dialogue I explained that she taught school for many years and had tried to land a couple of jobs, but was unsuccessful mostly due to her age and lack of experience in the fields she sought employment.  Having made a decision to become a bag lady, goes to this bridge, leaves her car, and has her first encounter with a homeless person.  In Jane's mind, she needs a grocery cart, so begins the conversation (dialogue) between the two:  Seeking the most likely person to engage in conversation with, she approaches a man squatting in front of a makeshift hut.  

 

                            “Hello, I’m Jane.  Nice to meet you.  I’m going to be your neighbor. Is the space beside you taken?”

 

                              He looks up at her as though she was from Mars.  

 

                             “I’m not the mayor of this place” he says, waving his hand in a large arc for effect. 

 

                             “You can settle in anywhere you see a space.  Did you walk over from town?  I never seen you on the strip. 

 

                             What's your name?”

 

                            “I told you it is Jane and I need a grocery cart too” Jane replies beginning to get exasperated . 

 

                            “Where might I procure such cart?”

 

                            “Huh”, he shrugs, “I don’t know you.  We ain’t a, you know, community.  Is every man for himself.”

 

            This short dialogue between Jane and the homeless man let the reader know Jane is not afraid to go where she has never been                                   before and his reply reveals he isn't going to help her.  Her vocabulary is richer and proper.  His indicates to the reader that he probably hasn't had a lot of education.  After all he is homeless.  Was I successful in giving the reader an image of each character?  If the reader has any prior knowledge of a homeless person, male or female walking down a city street pushing a grocery cart, and living in a box, then yes this dialogue has succeeded in giving the reader a more complete picture of the characters.  My character Jane has one more encounter with a group of women before she gives up and leaves the shanty surroundings:

                            

                            “Excuse me, can any of you give me some information about residing here and acquiring a grocery cart?” 

 

                            “We ain’t got no grocery carts.    Might can hang around the parking lot at the Price Chopper see if you can grab one left 

 

                            outside after they closes.  Round 10:00  tonight.”

 

                            “Oh, I didn’t know they are that hard to get.  Can’t I buy one?” Jane inquires.  

 

                            “Buy one? Lady you be lucky to find one with four wheels and one them handles to push it.  

 

                             We never had no high society beggar woman here before. You need to move on.”

 

Jane stays polite, on point to achieve her goal of finding a place to bed down for the night and getting that all important grocery cart, a prop she thinks is part of the whole homeless experience.  The woman she talks to suggests through dialogue that she steal one after hours at a grocery store, if she can find one that isn't missing a wheel or guiding handle.  She sizes up Jane, becomes the spokesman for the group and tells Jane not to give up trying, but to move on.  Direct, and to the point.  An example of the character of both women through my interpretation and understanding of these two very different individuals.

                             “I’m not the mayor of this place” he says, waving his hand in a large arc for effect. 

 

                             “You can settle in anywhere you see a space.  Did you walk over from town?  I never seen you on the strip. 

 

                             What's your name?”

 

                            “I told you it is Jane and I need a grocery cart too” Jane replies beginning to get exasperated . 

 

                            “Where might I procure such cart?”

 

                            “Huh”, he shrugs, “I don’t know you.  We ain’t a, you know, community.  Is every man for himself.”

 

            This short dialogue between Jane and the homeless man let the reader know Jane is not afraid to go where she has never been                                   before and his reply reveals he isn't going to help her.  Her vocabulary is richer and proper.  His indicates to the reader that he probably hasn't had a lot of education.  After all he is homeless.  Was I successful in giving the reader an image of each character?  If the reader has any prior knowledge of a homeless person, male or female walking down a city street pushing a grocery cart, and living in a box, then yes this dialogue has succeeded in giving the reader a more complete picture of the characters.  My character Jane has one more encounter with a group of women before she gives up and leaves the shanty surroundings:

                            

                            “Excuse me, can any of you give me some information about residing here and acquiring a grocery cart?” 

 

                            “We ain’t got no grocery carts.    Might can hang around the parking lot at the Price Chopper see if you can grab one left 

 

                            outside after they closes.  Round 10:00  tonight.”

 

                            “Oh, I didn’t know they are that hard to get.  Can’t I buy one?” Jane inquires.  

 

                            “Buy one? Lady you be lucky to find one with four wheels and one them handles to push it.  

 

                             We never had no high society beggar woman here before. You need to move on.”

 

Jane stays polite, on point to achieve her goal of finding a place to bed down for the night and getting that all important grocery cart, a prop she thinks is part of the whole homeless experience.  The woman she talks to suggests through dialogue that she steal one after hours at a grocery store, if she can find one that isn't missing a wheel or guiding handle.  She sizes up Jane, becomes the spokesman for the group and tells Jane not to give up trying, but to move on.  Direct, and to the point.  An example of the character of both women through my interpretation and understanding of these two very different individuals.

                            “Hello, I’m Jane.  Nice to meet you.  I’m going to be your neighbor. Is the space beside you taken?”

 

                              He looks up at her as though she was from Mars.  

 

                             “I’m not the mayor of this place” he says, waving his hand in a large arc for effect. 

 

                             “You can settle in anywhere you see a space.  Did you walk over from town?  I never seen you on the strip. 

 

                             What's your name?”

 

                            “I told you it is Jane and I need a grocery cart too” Jane replies beginning to get exasperated . 

 

                            “Where might I procure such cart?”

 

                            “Huh”, he shrugs, “I don’t know you.  We ain’t a, you know, community.  Is every man for himself.”

I wrote a short story over the summer while attending the Writer's Retreat at the Hemmingway-Pfieffer Educational Center.  There is one main character, an older lady like myself who is now retired with too much time on her hands.  I decided to have her try and become a “bag lady”, joining the homeless who live under a bridge in north Jonesboro.  It was my first experience using dialogue to give the reader insight into this character and the group of people she meets and tries to befriend.  It was especially important to show the way the words of each individual were spoken because of the difference in their social and economic worlds.  I titled my story “Jane, The Baglady.”  To give the reader some background into Jane before she had an dialogue I explained that she taught school for many years and had tried to land a couple of jobs, but was unsuccessful mostly due to her age and lack of experience in the fields she sought employment.  Having made a decision to become a bag lady, goes to this bridge, leaves her car, and has her first encounter with a homeless person.  In Jane's mind, she needs a grocery cart, so begins the conversation (dialogue) between the two:  Seeking the most likely person to engage in conversation with, she approaches a man squatting in front of a makeshift hut.  

 

                            “Hello, I’m Jane.  Nice to meet you.  I’m going to be your neighbor. Is the space beside you taken?”

 

                              He looks up at her as though she was from Mars.  

 

                             “I’m not the mayor of this place” he says, waving his hand in a large arc for effect. 

 

                             “You can settle in anywhere you see a space.  Did you walk over from town?  I never seen you on the strip. 

 

                             What's your name?”

 

                            “I told you it is Jane and I need a grocery cart too” Jane replies beginning to get exasperated . 

 

                            “Where might I procure such cart?”

 

                            “Huh”, he shrugs, “I don’t know you.  We ain’t a, you know, community.  Is every man for himself.”

 

            This short dialogue between Jane and the homeless man let the reader know Jane is not afraid to go where she has never been                                   before and his reply reveals he isn't going to help her.  Her vocabulary is richer and proper.  His indicates to the reader that he probably hasn't had a lot of education.  After all he is homeless.  Was I successful in giving the reader an image of each character?  If the reader has any prior knowledge of a homeless person, male or female walking down a city street pushing a grocery cart, and living in a box, then yes this dialogue has succeeded in giving the reader a more complete picture of the characters.  My character Jane has one more encounter with a group of women before she gives up and leaves the shanty surroundings:

                            

                            “Excuse me, can any of you give me some information about residing here and acquiring a grocery cart?” 

 

                            “We ain’t got no grocery carts.    Might can hang around the parking lot at the Price Chopper see if you can grab one left 

 

                            outside after they closes.  Round 10:00  tonight.”

 

                            “Oh, I didn’t know they are that hard to get.  Can’t I buy one?” Jane inquires.  

 

                            “Buy one? Lady you be lucky to find one with four wheels and one them handles to push it.  

 

                             We never had no high society beggar woman here before. You need to move on.”

 

Jane stays polite, on point to achieve her goal of finding a place to bed down for the night and getting that all important grocery cart, a prop she thinks is part of the whole homeless experience.  The woman she talks to suggests through dialogue that she steal one after hours at a grocery store, if she can find one that isn't missing a wheel or guiding handle.  She sizes up Jane, becomes the spokesman for the group and tells Jane not to give up trying, but to move on.  Direct, and to the point.  An example of the character of both women through my interpretation and understanding of these two very different individuals.

 

Jane reveals her character through dialog.  My intent of the use of the interplay of words between the homeless man and woman are to help the reader infer that Jane is not going to be successful as a bag lady, and as revealed when she returns home, her life isn't so bad after all.  Dialogue, to me, is a valuable writing techniques

I wrote a short story over the summer while attending the Writer's Retreat at the Hemmingway-Pfieffer Educational Center.  There is one main character, an older lady like myself who is now retired with too much time on her hands.  I decided to have her try and become a “bag lady”, joining the homeless who live under a bridge in north Jonesboro.  It was my first experience using dialogue to give the reader insight into this character and the group of people she meets and tries to befriend.  It was especially important to show the way the words of each individual were spoken because of the difference in their social and economic worlds.  I titled my story “Jane, The Baglady.”  To give the reader some background into Jane before she had an dialogue I explained that she taught school for many years and had tried to land a couple of jobs, but was unsuccessful mostly due to her age and lack of experience in the fields she sought employment.  Having made a decision to become a bag lady, goes to this bridge, leaves her car, and has her first encounter with a homeless person.  In Jane's mind, she needs a grocery cart, so begins the conversation (dialogue) between the two:  Seeking the most likely person to engage in conversation with, she approaches a man squatting in front of a makeshift hut.  

 

                            “Hello, I’m Jane.  Nice to meet you.  I’m going to be your neighbor. Is the space beside you taken?”

 

                              He looks up at her as though she was from Mars.  

 

                             “I’m not the mayor of this place” he says, waving his hand in a large arc for effect. 

 

                             “You can settle in anywhere you see a space.  Did you walk over from town?  I never seen you on the strip. 

 

                             What's your name?”

 

                            “I told you it is Jane and I need a grocery cart too” Jane replies beginning to get exasperated . 

 

                            “Where might I procure such cart?”

 

                            “Huh”, he shrugs, “I don’t know you.  We ain’t a, you know, community.  Is every man for himself.”

 

            This short dialogue between Jane and the homeless man let the reader know Jane is not afraid to go where she has never been                                   before and his reply reveals he isn't going to help her.  Her vocabulary is richer and proper.  His indicates to the reader that he probably hasn't had a lot of education.  After all he is homeless.  Was I successful in giving the reader an image of each character?  If the reader has any prior knowledge of a homeless person, male or female walking down a city street pushing a grocery cart, and living in a box, then yes this dialogue has succeeded in giving the reader a more complete picture of the characters.  My character Jane has one more encounter with a group of women before she gives up and leaves the shanty surroundings:

                            

                            “Excuse me, can any of you give me some information about residing here and acquiring a grocery cart?” 

 

                            “We ain’t got no grocery carts.    Might can hang around the parking lot at the Price Chopper see if you can grab one left 

 

                            outside after they closes.  Round 10:00  tonight.”

 

                            “Oh, I didn’t know they are that hard to get.  Can’t I buy one?” Jane inquires.  

 

                            “Buy one? Lady you be lucky to find one with four wheels and one them handles to push it.  

 

                             We never had no high society beggar woman here before. You need to move on.”

 

Jane stays polite, on point to achieve her goal of finding a place to bed down for the night and getting that all important grocery cart, a prop she thinks is part of the whole homeless experience.  The woman she talks to suggests through dialogue that she steal one after hours at a grocery store, if she can find one that isn't missing a wheel or guiding handle.  She sizes up Jane, becomes the spokesman for the group and tells Jane not to give up trying, but to move on.  Direct, and to the point.  An example of the character of both women through my interpretation and understanding of these two very different individuals.

 

Jane reveals her character through dialog.  My intent of the use of the interplay of words between the homeless man and woman are to help the reader infer that Jane is not going to be successful as a bag lady, and as revealed when she returns home, her life isn't so bad after all.  Dialogue, to me, is a valuable writing technique in the development of a whole, and interesting character or characters that make the reader want to turn the page

I wrote a short story over the summer while attending the Writer's Retreat at the Hemmingway-Pfieffer Educational Center.  There is one main character, an older lady like myself who is now retired with too much time on her hands.  I decided to have her try and become a “bag lady”, joining the homeless who live under a bridge in north Jonesboro.  It was my first experience using dialogue to give the reader insight into this character and the group of people she meets and tries to befriend.  It was especially important to show the way the words of each individual were spoken because of the difference in their social and economic worlds.  I titled my story “Jane, The Baglady.”  To give the reader some background into Jane before she speaks, I explained that she taught school for many years and had tried to land a couple of jobs, but was unsuccessful mostly due to her age and lack of experience in the fields she sought employment.  Having made a decision to become a bag lady, goes to this bridge, leaves her car, and has her first encounter with a homeless person.  In Jane's mind, she needs a grocery cart, so begins the conversation (dialogue) between the two:  Seeking the most likely person to engage in conversation with, she approaches a man squatting in front of a makeshift hut.  

 

                            “Hello, I’m Jane.  Nice to meet you.  I’m going to be your neighbor. Is the space beside you taken?”

 

                              He looks up at her as though she was from Mars.  

 

                             “I’m not the mayor of this place” he says, waving his hand in a large arc for effect. 

 

                             “You can settle in anywhere you see a space.  Did you walk over from town?  I never seen you on the strip. 

 

                             What's your name?”

 

                            “I told you it is Jane and I need a grocery cart too” Jane replies beginning to get exasperated . 

 

                            “Where might I procure such cart?”

 

                            “Huh”, he shrugs, “I don’t know you.  We ain’t a, you know, community.  Is every man for himself.”

 

            This short dialogue between Jane and the homeless man let the reader know Jane is not afraid to go where she has never been                                   before and his reply reveals he isn't going to help her.  Her vocabulary is richer and proper.  His indicates to the reader that he probably hasn't had a lot of education.  After all he is homeless.  Was I successful in giving the reader an image of each character?  If the reader has any prior knowledge of a homeless person, male or female walking down a city street pushing a grocery cart, and living in a box, then yes this dialogue has succeeded in giving the reader a more complete picture of the characters.  My character Jane has one more encounter with a group of women before she gives up and leaves the shanty surroundings:

                            

                            “Excuse me, can any of you give me some information about residing here and acquiring a grocery cart?” 

 

                            “We ain’t got no grocery carts.    Might can hang around the parking lot at the Price Chopper see if you can grab one left 

 

                            outside after they closes.  Round 10:00  tonight.”

 

                            “Oh, I didn’t know they are that hard to get.  Can’t I buy one?” Jane inquires.  

 

                            “Buy one? Lady you be lucky to find one with four wheels and one them handles to push it.  

 

                             We never had no high society beggar woman here before. You need to move on.”

 

Jane stays polite, on point to achieve her goal of finding a place to bed down for the night and getting that all important grocery cart, a prop she thinks is part of the whole homeless experience.  The woman she talks to suggests through dialogue that she steal one after hours at a grocery store, if she can find one that isn't missing a wheel or guiding handle.  She sizes up Jane, becomes the spokesman for the group and tells Jane not to give up trying, but to move on.  Direct, and to the point.  An example of the character of both women through my interpretation and understanding of these two very different individuals.

 

Jane reveals her character through dialog.  My intent of the use of the interplay of words between the homeless man and woman are to help the reader infer that Jane is not going to be successful as a bag lady, and as revealed when she returns home, her life isn't so bad after all.  Dialogue, to me, is a valuable writing technique in the development of a whole, and interesting character or characters that make the reader want to turn the page for more and become fully invested in the story.

I wrote a short story over the summer while attending the Writer's Retreat at the Hemmingway-Pfieffer Educational Center.  There is one main character, an older lady like myself who is now retired with too much time on her hands.  I decided to have her try and become a “bag lady”, joining the homeless who live under a bridge in north Jonesboro.  It was my first experience using dialogue to give the reader insight into this character and the group of people she meets and tries to befriend.  It was especially important to show the way the words of each individual were spoken because of the difference in their social and economic worlds.  I titled my story “Jane, The Baglady.”  To give the reader some background into Jane before she speaks, I explained that she taught school for many years and had tried to land a couple of jobs, but was unsuccessful mostly due to her age and lack of experience in the fields she sought employment.  Having made a decision to become a bag lady, she goes to this bridge, leaves her car, and has her first encounter with a homeless person.  In Jane's mind, she needs a grocery cart to fully become a bag lady.  So begins the conversation (dialogue) between the two:  

 

Seeking the most likely person to engage in conversation with, she approaches a man squatting in front of a makeshift hut.  

 

                            “Hello, I’m Jane.  Nice to meet you.  I’m going to be your neighbor. Is the space beside you taken?”

 

                              He looks up at her as though she was from Mars.  

 

                             “I’m not the mayor of this place” he says, waving his hand in a large arc for effect. 

 

                             “You can settle in anywhere you see a space.  Did you walk over from town?  I never seen you on the strip. 

 

                             What's your name?”

 

                            “I told you it is Jane and I need a grocery cart too” Jane replies beginning to get exasperated . 

 

                            “Where might I procure such cart?”

 

                            “Huh”, he shrugs, “I don’t know you.  We ain’t a, you know, community.  Is every man for himself.”

 

            This short dialogue between Jane and the homeless man let the reader know Jane is not afraid to go where she has never been                                   before and his reply reveals he isn't going to help her.  Her vocabulary is richer and proper.  His indicates to the reader that he probably hasn't had a lot of education.  After all he is homeless.  Was I successful in giving the reader an image of each character?  If the reader has any prior knowledge of a homeless person, male or female walking down a city street pushing a grocery cart, and living in a box, then yes this dialogue has succeeded in giving the reader a more complete picture of the characters.  My character Jane has one more encounter with a group of women before she gives up and leaves the shanty surroundings:

                            

                            “Excuse me, can any of you give me some information about residing here and acquiring a grocery cart?” 

 

                            “We ain’t got no grocery carts.    Might can hang around the parking lot at the Price Chopper see if you can grab one left 

 

                            outside after they closes.  Round 10:00  tonight.”

 

                            “Oh, I didn’t know they are that hard to get.  Can’t I buy one?” Jane inquires.  

 

                            “Buy one? Lady you be lucky to find one with four wheels and one them handles to push it.  

 

                             We never had no high society beggar woman here before. You need to move on.”

 

Jane stays polite, on point to achieve her goal of finding a place to bed down for the night and getting that all important grocery cart, a prop she thinks is part of the whole homeless experience.  The woman she talks to suggests through dialogue that she steal one after hours at a grocery store, if she can find one that isn't missing a wheel or guiding handle.  She sizes up Jane, becomes the spokesman for the group and tells Jane not to give up trying, but to move on.  Direct, and to the point.  An example of the character of both women through my interpretation and understanding of these two very different individuals.

 

Jane reveals her character through dialog.  My intent of the use of the interplay of words between the homeless man and woman are to help the reader infer that Jane is not going to be successful as a bag lady, and as revealed when she returns home, her life isn't so bad after all.  Dialogue, to me, is a valuable writing technique in the development of a whole, and interesting character or characters that make the reader want to turn the page for more and become fully invested in the story.

I wrote a short story over the summer while attending the Writer's Retreat at the Hemmingway-Pfieffer Educational Center.  There is one main character, an older lady like myself who is now retired with too much time on her hands.  I decided to have her try and become a “bag lady”, joining the homeless who live under a bridge in north Jonesboro.  It was my first experience using dialogue to give the reader insight into this character and the group of people she meets and tries to befriend.  It was especially important to show the way the words of each individual were spoken because of the difference in their social and economic worlds.  I titled my story “Jane, The Baglady.”  To give the reader some background into Jane before she speaks, I explained that she taught school for many years and had tried to land a couple of jobs, but was unsuccessful mostly due to her age and lack of experience in the fields she sought employment.  Having made a decision to become a bag lady, she goes to this bridge, leaves her car, and has her first encounter with a homeless person.  In Jane's mind, she needs a grocery cart to fully become a bag lady.  So begins the conversation (dialogue) between the two:  

 

Seeking the most likely person to engage in conversation with, she approaches a man squatting in front of a makeshift hut.  

 

                            “Hello, I’m Jane.  Nice to meet you.  I’m going to be your neighbor. Is the space beside you taken?”

 

                              He looks up at her as though she was from Mars.  

 

                             “I’m not the mayor of this place” he says, waving his hand in a large arc for effect. 

 

                             “You can settle in anywhere you see a space.  Did you walk over from town?  I never seen you on the strip. 

 

                             What's your name?”

 

                            “I told you it is Jane and I need a grocery cart too” Jane replies beginning to get exasperated . 

 

                            “Where might I procure such cart?”

 

                            “Huh”, he shrugs, “I don’t know you.  We ain’t a, you know, community.  Is every man for himself.”

 

            This short dialogue between Jane and the homeless man let the reader know Jane is not afraid to go where she has never been                                   before and his reply reveals he isn't going to help her.  Her vocabulary is richer and proper.  His indicates to the reader that he probably hasn't had a lot of education.  After all he is homeless.  Was I successful in giving the reader an image of each character?  If the reader has any prior knowledge of a homeless person, male or female, walking down a city street pushing a grocery cart, and living in a box, then yes this dialogue has succeeded in giving the reader a more complete picture of the characters.  My character Jane has one more encounter with a group of women before she gives up and leaves the shanty surroundings.  The dialog:

                            

                            “Excuse me, can any of you give me some information about residing here and acquiring a grocery cart?” 

 

                            “We ain’t got no grocery carts.    Might can hang around the parking lot at the Price Chopper see if you can grab one left 

 

                            outside after they closes.  Round 10:00  tonight.”

 

                            “Oh, I didn’t know they are that hard to get.  Can’t I buy one?” Jane inquires.  

 

                            “Buy one? Lady you be lucky to find one with four wheels and one them handles to push it.  

 

                             We never had no high society beggar woman here before. You need to move on.”

 

Jane stays polite, on point to achieve her goal of finding a place to bed down for the night and getting that all important grocery cart, a prop she thinks is part of the whole homeless experience.  The woman she talks to suggests through dialogue that she steal one after hours at a grocery store, if she can find one that isn't missing a wheel or guiding handle.  She sizes up Jane, becomes the spokesman for the group and tells Jane not to give up trying, but to move on.  Direct, and to the point.  An example of the character of both women through my interpretation and understanding of these two very different individuals.

 

Jane reveals her character through dialog.  My intent of the use of the interplay of words between the homeless man and woman are to help the reader infer that Jane is not going to be successful as a bag lady, and as revealed when she returns home, her life isn't so bad after all.  Dialogue, to me, is a valuable writing technique in the development of a whole, and interesting character or characters that make the reader want to turn the page for more and become fully invested in the story.

I wrote a short story over the summer while attending the Writer's Retreat at the Hemmingway-Pfieffer Educational Center.  There is one main character, an older lady like myself who is now retired with too much time on her hands.  I decided to have her try and become a “bag lady”, joining the homeless who live under a bridge in north Jonesboro.  It was my first experience using dialogue to give the reader insight into this character and the group of people she meets and tries to befriend.  It was especially important to show the way the words of each individual were spoken because of the difference in their social and economic worlds.  I titled my story “Jane, The Baglady.”  To give the reader some background into Jane before she speaks, I explained that she taught school for many years and had tried to land a couple of jobs, but was unsuccessful mostly due to her age and lack of experience in the fields she sought employment.  Having made a decision to become a bag lady, she goes to this bridge, leaves her car, and has her first encounter with a homeless person.  In Jane's mind, she needs a grocery cart to fully become a bag lady.  So begins the conversation (dialogue) between the two:  

 

Seeking the most likely person to engage in conversation with, she approaches a man squatting in front of a makeshift hut.  

 

                            “Hello, I’m Jane.  Nice to meet you.  I’m going to be your neighbor. Is the space beside you taken?”

 

                              He looks up at her as though she was from Mars.  

 

                             “I’m not the mayor of this place” he says, waving his hand in a large arc for effect. 

 

                             “You can settle in anywhere you see a space.  Did you walk over from town?  I never seen you on the strip. 

 

                             What's your name?”

 

                            “I told you it is Jane and I need a grocery cart too” Jane replies beginning to get exasperated . 

 

                            “Where might I procure such cart?”

 

                            “Huh”, he shrugs, “I don’t know you.  We ain’t a, you know, community.  Is every man for himself.”

 

            This short dialogue between Jane and the homeless man let the reader know Jane is not afraid to go where she has never been                                   before and his reply reveals he isn't going to help her.  Her vocabulary is richer and proper.  His indicates to the reader that he probably hasn't had a lot of education.  After all he is homeless.  Was I successful in giving the reader an image of each character?  If the reader has any prior knowledge of a homeless person, male or female, walking down a city street pushing a grocery cart, and living in a box, then yes this dialogue has succeeded in giving the reader a more complete picture of the characters.  My character Jane has one more encounter with a group of women before she gives up and leaves the shanty surroundings.  The dialog:

                            

                            “Excuse me, can any of you give me some information about residing here and acquiring a grocery cart?” 

 

                            “We ain’t got no grocery carts.    Might can hang around the parking lot at the Price Chopper see if you can grab one left 

 

                            outside after they closes.  Round 10:00  tonight.”

 

                            “Oh, I didn’t know they are that hard to get.  Can’t I buy one?” Jane inquires.  

 

                            “Buy one? Lady you be lucky to find one with four wheels and one them handles to push it.  

 

                             We ain't never had no high society beggar woman here before. You need to move on.”

 

Jane stays polite, on point to achieve her goal of finding a place to bed down for the night and getting that all important grocery cart, a prop she thinks is part of the whole homeless experience.  The woman she talks to suggests, through dialogue, that she steal one after hours at a grocery store, if she can find one that isn't missing a wheel or a guiding handle.  She sizes Jane up, becomes the spokesman for the group and tells Jane not to give up trying, but to move on.  Direct, and to the point.  An example of the character of both women through my interpretation and understanding of these two very different individuals.

Seeking the most likely person to engage in conversation with, she approaches a man squatting in front of a makeshift hut.  

 

                            “Hello, I’m Jane.  Nice to meet you.  I’m going to be your neighbor. Is the space beside you taken?”

 

                              He looks up at her as though she was from Mars.  

 

                             “I’m not the mayor of this place” he says, waving his hand in a large arc for effect. 

 

                             “You can settle in anywhere you see a space.  Did you walk over from town?  I never seen you on the strip. 

 

                             What's your name?”

                            outside after they closes.  Round 10:00  tonight.”
